sn6.14:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.
sn6.14:5.1: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Aruṇavā.
sn6.14:5.2: He had a capital named Aruṇavatī.
sn6.14:5.3: Sikhī the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha lived supported by Aruṇavatī.
sn6.14:5.4: Sikhī had a fine pair of chief disciples named Abhibhū and Sambhava.
sn6.14:5.5: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū:
sn6.14:5.6: ‘Come, brahmin, let’s go to one of the brahmā realms until it’s time for our meal.’
sn6.14:5.9: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn6.14:5.11: they vanished from Aruṇavatī and appeared in that Brahmā realm.
sn6.14:6.1: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū:
sn6.14:6.2: ‘Brahmin, teach the Dhamma as you feel inspired for that Brahmā, his assembly, and the members of his retinue.”
sn6.14:6.3: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
sn6.14:6.4: But the Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue complained, grumbled, and objected:
sn6.14:6.5: ‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! How on earth can a disciple teach Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher?’
sn6.14:7.1: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicant Abhibhū:
sn6.14:7.2: ‘Brahmin, Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue are complaining
sn6.14:7.3: that a disciple teaches Dhamma in the presence of the Teacher.
sn6.14:7.4: Well then, brahmin, stir them up even more!’
sn6.14:7.5: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Then he taught Dhamma with his body visible; with his body invisible; with the lower half visible and the upper half invisible; and with the upper half visible and the lower half invisible.
sn6.14:7.6: And the Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought:
sn6.14:7.7: ‘It’s incredible, it’s amazing! The ascetic has such psychic power and might!’
sn6.14:8.1: Then Abhibhū said to the Buddha Sikhī:
sn6.14:8.2: ‘Sir, I recall having said this in the middle of the Saṅgha:
sn6.14:8.3: “Standing in the Brahmā realm, I can make my voice heard throughout the galaxy.”’
sn6.14:8.4: ‘Now is the time, brahmin! Now is the time, brahmin!
sn6.14:8.5: Standing in the Brahmā realm, make your voice heard throughout the galaxy.’
sn6.14:8.6: ‘Yes, sir,’ replied Abhibhū. Standing in the Brahmā realm, he recited this verse:
sn6.14:9.2: Devote yourselves to the teachings of the Buddha!
sn6.14:9.4: like an elephant crushes a hut of reeds.
sn6.14:10.4: will make an end of suffering.’
sn6.14:11.1: Having inspired that Brahmā, his assembly, and his retinue with a sense of awe,
sn6.14:11.2: as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn6.14:11.3: Sikhī and Abhibhū vanished from that Brahmā realm and appeared in Aruṇavatī.
sn6.14:11.4: Then the Buddha Sikhī addressed the mendicants:
sn6.14:11.5: ‘Mendicants, did you hear the mendicant Abhibhū speaking a verse while standing in a Brahmā realm?’
sn6.14:12.2: Devote yourselves to the teachings of the Buddha!
sn6.14:12.4: like an elephant crushes a hut of reeds.
sn6.14:13.4: will make an end of suffering.”
sn6.14:14.3: It’s good that you heard the mendicant Abhibhū speaking this verse while standing in a Brahmā realm.’”
sn6.14:15.1: This is what the Buddha said. Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
